hints_html: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus only applies to functions that are continuous on the entire domain of integration.
hints_latex:
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus only applies to functions that are
continuous on the entire domain of integration.
hints_raw: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus only applies to functions that are continuous on the entire domain of integration.
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
Following the hint we check if the integrands above are continuous on the entire domain of integration.

i. \(\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{\ln x} \, dx.\) Since \(\ln x\) is not even defined for negative numbers, the integrand \(\frac{\cos x}{\ln x}\) is certainly not continuous on \((-1,1)\).

ii. \(\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{x} \, dx.\) The integrand is not defined for x=0, so it is certainly not continuous on \((-1,1)\).

iii. \(\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{\sqrt{x}+1} \, dx.\) Since \(\sqrt x\) is not even defined for negative numbers, the integrand \(\frac{\cos x}{\sqrt{x}+1}\) is certainly not continuous on \((-1,1)\).

iv. \(\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{x^2+1} \, dx.\) Here the integrand is defined everywhere. As a composition of continuous functions, the integrand is continuous. Hence the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus applies here.

Final answer: iv.
sols_latex:
Following the hint we check if the integrands above are continuous on
the entire domain of integration.

i. $\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{\ln x} \, dx.$ Since $\ln x$ is not even
defined for negative numbers, the integrand $\frac{\cos x}{\ln x}$ is
certainly not continuous on $(-1,1)$.

ii. $\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{x} \, dx.$ The integrand is not defined
for \emph{x=0}, so it is certainly not continuous on $(-1,1)$.

iii. $\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{\sqrt{x}+1} \, dx.$ Since $\sqrt x$ is
not even defined for negative numbers, the integrand
$\frac{\cos x}{\sqrt{x}+1}$ is certainly not continuous on $(-1,1)$.

iv. $\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{x^2+1} \, dx.$ Here the integrand is
defined everywhere. As a composition of continuous functions, the
integrand is continuous. Hence the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
applies here.

\textbf{Final answer: iv.}
sols_raw:
Following the hint we check if the integrands above are continuous on the entire domain of integration.


i. <math>\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{\ln x} \, dx.</math> Since <math>\ln x</math> is not even defined for negative numbers, the integrand <math>\frac{\cos x}{\ln x}</math> is certainly not continuous on <math>(-1,1)</math>.

ii. <math>\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{x} \, dx.</math> The integrand is not defined for ''x=0'', so it is certainly not continuous on <math>(-1,1)</math>.

iii. <math>\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{\sqrt{x}+1} \, dx.</math> Since <math>\sqrt x</math> is not even defined for negative numbers, the integrand <math> \frac{\cos x}{\sqrt{x}+1} </math> is certainly not continuous on <math>(-1,1)</math>.

iv. <math>\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{x^2+1} \, dx.</math> Here the integrand is defined everywhere. As a composition of continuous functions, the integrand is continuous. Hence the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus applies here.


'''Final answer: iv.'''
statement_html:
Multiple Choice Question: Exactly ONE of the answers provided is correct. There is no partial credit in this questions.

To which of the following integrals does the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus apply?

i. \(\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{\ln x} \, dx\)

ii. \(\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{x} \, dx\)

iii. \(\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{\sqrt{x}+1} \, dx\)

iv. \(\int_{-1}^1\frac{\cos x}{x^2+1} \, dx\)

v. None of the above.
